thread.title: Lancaster passes tougher laws for keeping animals outside
thread.title_full: Lancaster passes tougher laws for keeping animals outside | The Columbus Dispatch

author: The Columbus Dispatch
title: Lancaster passes tougher laws for keeping animals outside
text:
After numerous complaints, Lancaster city and humane-society officials worked to develop specific rules to ensure that animals left outside have proper shelter and reliable access to food and water. 

Tonight, the Lancaster City Council approved an ordinance creating those rules. 

Councilwoman Becky Tener, who sponsored the legislation, said she had received frequent calls about animals left outside in less-than-ideal conditions. 

“People are tying tarps over picnic tables, benches,” Tener said. “That’s not a proper shelter for a dog.” 

The ordinance, passed by a vote of 8-1, goes beyond current state law for leaving pets outdoors, which calls for a sufficient supply of food and water and access to shelter from the elements. 

The Lancaster ordinance requires water bowls to either be weighted or mounted to prevent tipping, and prohibits animal owners or caretakers from tethering or restraining an animal in any way that could cause injury or entanglement. 

It also calls for dry, enclosed and insulated shelters with one entrance. Shelters also must have moisture-proof flooring that is raised at least 2 inches from the ground. 

The changes make the rules more enforceable for humane officers, Tener said. 

Some cities have passed additional rules for keeping pets outside, but many continue to follow the guidelines of the Ohio Revised Code, said Teresa Landon, executive director of the Ohio Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. 

“Any time that a city or a municipality makes a move to strengthen, to go above the Ohio Revised Code, it’s a good step,” she said. 

The state rules leave a lot of gray area, said Fairfield Area Humane Society Executive Director Corey Schoonover, who helped develop the Lancaster ordinance. The new rules enhance the humane officers’ ability to ensure people take better care of their outdoor pets, he said. 

But the ordinance could create a burden for citizens, said Councilman Mike Fracassa, the only “no’ vote in tonight’s decision. The ordinance doesn’t differentiate clearly between outdoor and indoor pets, he said. 

“It’s too restrictive; it’s not clear as to what pets we’re talking about,” he said. “I definitely favor enforcement against animal abuse, but this is just taking things too far.”
